Comment: No clear morphological class of adjectives: roots can be used as nouns, verbs, or adjectives (Estigarribia 2020: 87). To function as independent predicates, roots must take verbal personal markers (prefixes).
Bare roots cannot function as independent predicates. However, this is ungrammatical only as a sentence, not as a DP.
Forms with the suffix -va (adjectivizer/relativizer) cannot be used predicatively. However, this is ungrammatical only as a sentence, not as a DP.

Translation: This woman is tired of work.
Comment: The word order with the dependent following the “adjective” (root with a verbal personal marker) seems to be the neutral/more natural one, but the alternative word order is possible as well.

Translation: This woman is tired of work.
Comment: The word order with the dependent following the “adjective” (root with a verbal personal marker) seems to be the neutral/more natural one, but the alternative word order is possible as well.

Translation: A tired woman is eating in the room.
Comment: Attributive modifiers can be bare roots or forms with the adjectivizer/relativizer -va, and they are normally placed postnominally.

Translation: A tired woman is eating in the room.
Comment: Attributive modifiers can be bare roots or forms with the adjectivizer/relativizer -va, and they are normally placed postnominally.

Translation: Intended: ‘A tired woman is eating in the room.’
Comment: Bare roots as modifiers can only be postnominal, while -va forms can also occur prenominally.

Translation: A tired woman is eating in the room.
Comment: Bare roots as modifiers can only be postnominal, while -va forms can also occur prenominally.

Translation: Intended: ‘A woman tired of work is eating in the room.’
Comment: Bare roots used as modifiers cannot take dependents.

Original: Peteĩ kuña ikane’õva omba’apógui okaru kotýpe.
Morphemic: peteĩ kuña ikane’õ-va o-mba’apo=gui o-karu koty=pe
Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: The prenominal placement of a complex AP/RC is not possible independently of the linear position of the dependent.

Original: Peteĩ kuña omba’apógui ikane’õva okaru kotýpe.

Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: The prenominal placement of a complex AP/RC is not possible independently of the linear position of the dependent.

Translation: Intended: ‘A woman tired of work is eating in the room.’
Comment: The prenominal placement of a complex AP/RC is not possible independently of the linear position of the dependent.

Translation: Intended: ‘A woman tired of work is eating in the room.’
Comment: The prenominal placement of a complex AP/RC is not possible independently of the linear position of the dependent

Translation: The knife (that is) on the table is clean
column10: ”The postnominal placement of adnominal PPs appears to be the neutral/more natural one. Such PPs are often introduced with an additional enclitic =gua.”

Translation: The knife (that is) on the table is clean.
Comment: The postnominal placement of adnominal PPs is also possible in this example.

Translation: S/he saw a car without passengers / anyone inside.
Comment: possm.3 = possessed form of relational roots (for third-person pronominal possessor.

Translation: Intended: ‘S/he saw a car without passengers / anyone inside.’
Comment: In this example, prenominal placement of PPs is not possible. But it remains (an open question is if this correlates with the presence/absence of =gua.
